title: U.S. stock futures mixed, with disappointing Snap, Twitter results weighing on the tech sector; Twitter reports misses across the board
text:
* Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average YM00 were flat at 32061.

* Futures on the S&P 500 ES00 dropped 6 points, or 0.1%, to 3995.25.

* Futures on the Nasdaq 100 NQ00 decreased 41 points, or 0.3%, to 12599.

On Thursday, the Dow industrials climbed 162.06 points, or 0.5%, to 32,036.90, the S&P 500 gained 1% to 3,998.95 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.4% to 12,059.61. It marked the third straight session of gains for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq and the highest levels in six weeks for all three indexes.

Investors cheered second-quarter earnings results for Tesla TSLA and Philip Morris International PM among others, which offered some salve for economic data such as weekly jobless claims that indicated a slowing economy.

Need to Know: UBS isn't yet a believer in the rally. Here's its advice on what to do now.

What's driving markets?

While all three indexes were looking at strong weekly gains — the Nasdaq was up 5.3% as of Thursday — disappointing results from Snapchat parent Snap SNAP were threatening to derail some of that earnings optimism. Those shares were down 27% ahead of Friday's open after the company revealed weak digital advertising, hinted at cost cuts and didn't provide a forecast.

"The Snap results came as a warning for other Big Tech names that rely on ad revenue," said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, senior analyst at Swissquote, in a note to clients.

Opinion: As Snap melts down, its founders make sure to protect the people who matter: themselves

Shares of Pinterest PINS slid 6%, Google parent Alphabet GOOGL fell 2.8% and that of Facebook parent Meta Platforms META dropped 4.7% in early premarket trading.

Twitter TWTR shares fell over 2% after the micro-messaging service reported earnings and revenue misses.

Next week will see some of the biggest tech names on Wall Street report, including Microsoft MSFT, Meta, Apple AAPL and Amazon AMZN, along with Boeing BA, McDonald's MCD and Caterpillar CAT.

Also reporting Friday, American Express AXP shares rose 4% after reporting a hefty earnings beat driven by strong consumer spending, and lifted its outlook for the year.

The U.S. economic data front is less busy on Friday, with the flash S&P Global U.S. manufacturing and services purchasing managers indexes due.

The 10-year Treasury yield BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell 11 basis points to 2.799% from 2.908% in the previous session as investor worries over a possible U.S. recession lingered.

The euro EURUSD was weaker against the dollar on Friday, trading down 0.6% at $1.0167, one day after the European Central Bank hiked interest rates for the first time in 11 years, following PMI data that showed a contraction in the eurozone. The German 10-year bund yield BX:TMBMKDE-10Y tumbled 19 basis points to 1.03%.

What companies are in focus?

* Verizon Communications Inc. stock VZ fell 4.4% in premarket after the telecommunications group cut full-year guidance and missed second-quarter earnings and revenue estimates.

* Schlumberger Ltd. SLB shares rose more than 2% after the oilfield equipment and services group reported better-than-expected results and lifted its outlook.

* Seagate Technology Holdings PLC STX shares slid 11% after the data-storage device group's results and outlook fell short of Wall Street expectations.

* Mattel Inc. MAT fell 1.5% in premarket after the toymaker reported a forecast-beating quarterly profit, but a 20% slump in sales of its American Girl business.

How are other assets trading?

* Oil futures were lower, with U.S. crude CL.1 CLU22 falling 75 cents, or 0.8%, to $95.59 a barrel, after slumping 3.5% on Thursday. Brent crude BRN00 BRNU22 , the global benchmark, fell $1.17, or 1.1%, to $102.76 a barrel, a day after sliding 2.9% to its lowest since July 15 of $103.86 a barrel.

* Gold GC00 GCQ22 rose $13.80, or 0.8%, to $1.727.10 an ounce.

* Bitcoin BTCUSD was higher at $23,639.

* The Stoxx Europe 600 index XX:SXXP rose 0.4%.

U.S. stock futures mixed, with disappointing Snap, Twitter results weighing on the tech sector
